title: 108_hr2768
content: The Act titled the "John Marshall Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes John Marshall's significant contributions as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court, where he shaped the fundamental principles of the Constitution, including judicial review. Marshall's extensive tenure and numerous influential opinions solidify his place as one of the most important figures in American history. The "John Marshall Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of $1 coins in honor of Chief Justice John Marshall's 250th birth anniversary. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins minted under the "John Marshall Commemorative Coin Act" shall symbolize Chief Justice John Marshall's contributions to the Constitution and the Supreme Court. Each coin will feature the coin's value, the year "2005", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Supreme Court Historical Society, and reviewed by the Citizens Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility starting January 1, 2005, with minting authority ending on December 31, 2005. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Marketing efforts will be developed in cooperation with the Legacy Fund of the Library of Congress. The Secretary will develop a marketing program to promote and sell the coins issued under this Act in the United States and internationally. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. All sales of coins minted under this Act include a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges received are promptly paid to the Supreme Court Historical Society for supporting historical research, educational programs, fellowship programs, internships, docents, and collecting historical items related to the Supreme Court and the Constitution of the United States. The Society is subject to audit requirements. The surcharge for coins minted under this Act is $10 per coin, which is paid to the Supreme Court Historical Society for various programs. There is a limitation on the number of commemorative coin programs issued each year to comply with the annual issuance limitation. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to enforce this limitation.
